intro: Alloplectus coccineus var. fuscomaculatus, commonly known as the red mallow or scarlet mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its showy, bright red or pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has heart-shaped leaves with a velvety texture and is often found in moist, open habitats such as wetlands and disturbed soils. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes other mallow species known for their hairy stems and capsule fruits. Alloplectus coccineus var. fuscomaculatus is an herbaceous perennial that can grow up to 2 feet tall, with a distinctive reddish stem and foliage.
